content.webTitle: Governor Bobby Jindal talks foreign policy: 'We are at war with radical Islam'

fields.headline: Governor Bobby Jindal talks foreign policy: 'We are at war with radical Islam'
fields.bodyText: Louisiana governor Bobby Jindal suggested on Monday that he would support barring people from the US for belief in “radical Islam”, in an apparent attempt to polish his hawkish foreign policy credentials and present himself as worthy name for Republicans’ 2016 ticket, possibly as a vice-presidential candidate. “In the west I believe we have a responsibility,” Jindal told the American Action Forum, a conservative thinktank, “to insist that those coming into our societies, those that come to our country, assimilate or integrate.” Qualifying vaguely that the US must not “discriminate against anybody” for their race or religion, Jindal said the US should not permit entry to people who would “use the freedoms we give them to undermine the freedoms we grant to everyone”. Jindal said he would “draw the line” with a test of intention. “You have the right to have whatever beliefs you want, you don’t have the right to impose those beliefs in a way that infringes on the freedoms of other people.” Asked about how such a view squares with Jindal’s own anti-abortion position and his attempt last year to shut down Louisiana’s two abortion clinics, Jindal hemmed and hawed before suggesting he meant only the “freedoms of self-expression, freedom of religion, freedom of speech”. “I would distinguish between people who are pro-life and radical Islamic terrorists, those are two different things,” he said. “It depends on the beliefs.” Jindal used Isis as his primary example but also said the first Muslim Brotherhood includes “ideologies that are hostile to our interests”. ‘If we don’t insist on’ assimilation we then go the way of Europe’ “So in other words we shouldn’t tolerate those who want to come and try to impose some variant of, some version of Sharia law,” Jindal said. “I fear if we don’t insist on” assimilation,” he said, “we then go the way of Europe.” European cities, he said warily and without specified examples, included neighborhoods in which women felt afraid to walk without veils. Jindal said it was “nonsense” that such remarks, which follow comments made in London about Muslim “no-go zones”, might be perceived as “racist or anti-Muslim”. He refused, however, to backtrack from any such comments, saying, “Islam has a problem.” In London Jindal made similar remarks, saying “it is completely reasonable for nations to discriminate between allowing people into their country who want to embrace their culture, or allowing people into their country who want to destroy their culture, or establish a separate culture within.” “Of course we’re not at war with Islam,” Jindal said in Washington, “but of course we are at war with radical Islam and radical Islamist terrorists”. Jindal’s own religious beliefs could be controversial should he reach the next plateau of politics. A convert to Catholicism at a young age, Jindal has courted the born-again Christians and evangelicals with increasing fervor in recent years, even as more Americans choose not to identify with any religion. During college, he also took part in a ritual that resembled an exorcism, though he did not use that word when he described the incident in a 1994 article. In that article Jindal describes a friend’s seizure-like spasms, replete with profane language directed at Jesus Christ, as he and others prayed around her. He concluded that article by saying he believes in “the reality of spirits, angels and other related phenomena that I can neither touch nor see.” Appointed Louisiana’s secretary of health as a 25-year-old who had been recently named an Oxford’s Rhodes scholar, Jindal was an ascendant starlet of the Republican party for years, winning conservatives as a congressman and governor who rejects all taxes and espouses social causes. Now 43, facing a mammoth $1.6bn budget shortfall in his state, and tacking right in search for national prominence, Jindal is now an outlier in a wide field of conservatives hoping to make a bid in the 2016 presidential election. In the unofficial straw poll taken at CPAC, conservatives’ annual conference, Jindal polled worse than Donald Trump, the reality television bigwig better known for his rufescent hair than his political acumen. Jindal said he is “a couple of months away” from deciding whether to run for president. Instead he appeared to be jostling for position as a vice-presidential candidate for whomever wins the Republican nomination. To that end he repeatedly mentioned several policy “plans” he had written on a number of topics, similar to the economic manifestos produced by Wisconsin representative Paul Ryan during the 2012 campaign. The governor also mentioned his policy on education, which has provoked criticism from academics for years for allowing creationism materials into classrooms, and for the years of budget cuts necessary due to Jindal’s refusal to raise taxes. Jindal said he believes “curriculum decisions should be made at the local level”, and that “we should be teaching English as our language, we should be teaching about American exceptionalism in our history classes.” He also took perfunctory jabs at President Obama and pushed for an expanded war against Isis in the Middle East: “You’ve got officials at the State Department saying, ‘We’re not going to kill our way out of this war,’ well how else do we win wars if not by killing our way to victory?”
